figures.description: Small laboratory setup shown beside Question 30 (includes a flask/bottle and a gas collection arrangement). Used with reaction \(2\text{HCl}_{(aq)} + \text{CaCO}_{3(s)} \rightarrow \text{CaCl}_{2(s)} + \text{CO}_{2(g)} + \text{H}_2\text{O}_{(l)}\) and curves labeled L, M, N, P for \(\text{CO}_2\) production.

questions.question: Which Question Paper Type of Chemistry is given to you?
questions.explanation: The header on the page states "PAPER TYPE: RED".

questions.question: Which of the following methods can be used to obtain pure water from a mixture of sand, water and methanoic acid?

options.text: neutralization with NaOH followed by filtration
neutralization with NaOH followed by distillation

questions.explanation: Sand is insoluble, so it is removed by filtration. The filtrate contains water and methanoic acid (miscible liquids), so distillation separates and collects the water as the distillate.

questions.question: How many atoms are present in 6.0 g of magnesium? [Mg = 24, \(N_A = 6.02 \times 10^{23}\,\text{mol}^{-1}\)]
questions.explanation: Moles of Mg \(= \frac{6.0}{24} = 0.25\,\text{mol}\). Number of atoms \(= 0.25\times 6.02\times 10^{23} = 1.505\times 10^{23}\approx 1.51\times 10^{23}\).

questions.question: 50 cm\(^3\) of gas was collected over water at 10\(^\circ\)C and 765 mmHg. Calculate the volume of the gas at s.t.p. if the saturated vapour pressure of water at 10\(^\circ\)C is 5 mmHg.
An increase in the pressure exerted on gas at a constant temperature result in

options.text: a decrease in the number of effective collisions
an increase in the average intermolecular distance

questions.explanation: At constant temperature, increasing pressure compresses a gas so its volume decreases (Boyle’s law).

questions.question: In the reaction \(2\text{H}_2(g) + \text{O}_2(g) \rightarrow 2\text{H}_2\text{O}(g)\), what volume of hydrogen would be left over when 300 cm\(^3\) of oxygen and 1000 cm\(^3\) of hydrogen are exploded in a sealed tube?
questions.explanation: Volume ratios follow coefficients: \(\text{H}_2:\text{O}_2 = 2:1\). For 300 cm\(^3\) \(\text{O}_2\), required \(\text{H}_2\) is \(2\times 300 = 600\) cm\(^3\). Leftover \(\text{H}_2 = 1000-600 = 400\) cm\(^3\).

questions.question: I. Evaporation. II. Sublimation. III. Diffusion. IV. Brownian motion. Which of the above can correctly be listed as evidences for the particulate nature of matter?
questions.explanation: All four phenomena depend on matter being made of particles in constant motion (especially diffusion and Brownian motion).

questions.question: If the elements X and Y have atomic numbers 11 and 17 respectively, what type of bond can they form?
questions.explanation: Atomic number 11 is Na (metal) and 17 is Cl (non-metal). Electron transfer forms \(\text{Na}^+\) and \(\text{Cl}^-\), i.e., an ionic bond.

questions.question: A hydrogen atom which has lost an electron contains

options.text: one proton, one electron and one neutron

questions.explanation: A neutral hydrogen atom (protium) is 1 proton + 1 electron. Losing the electron leaves \(\text{H}^+\), which is just one proton.

questions.question: The electronic configuration of \(\text{Mg}^{2+}\) is
questions.explanation: Neutral Mg (Z = 12): \(1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\). \(\text{Mg}^{2+}\) loses the two \(3s\) electrons, leaving \(1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\).

questions.question: Group VII elements are
questions.explanation: Halogens (Group VII/17) readily gain electrons, so they oxidize other substances (they are oxidizing agents).

questions.question: Which of the following is used to study the arrangement of particles in crystal lattices?
questions.explanation: Crystal structures are determined using X-ray diffraction.

questions.question: I. It has a varied composition from one place to another. II. its constituents can be separated by physical means III. It contains unreactive noble gases. Which of the above shows that air is a mixture?
questions.explanation: Air has variable composition, can be separated physically (e.g., fractionation of liquid air), and contains inert noble gases mixed with other gases—features of a mixture.

questions.question: The chemicals used to soften hard water involves the addition of

options.text: insoluble sodium compounds which form soluble solutions of calcium and magnesium
soluble sodium compounds which form soluble solutions of calcium and magnesium ions
soluble sodium compounds which form insoluble precipitates of calcium and magnesium ions
insoluble precipitates of calcium and magnesium ions

questions.explanation: Hardness is due to \(\text{Ca}^{2+}\) and \(\text{Mg}^{2+}\). Adding soluble sodium salts like \(\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3\) supplies \(\text{CO}_3^{2-}\) to form insoluble precipitates (e.g., \(\text{CaCO}_3\)), removing the ions.

questions.question: Chlorination of water for town supply is carried out to
questions.explanation: Chlorine disinfects water by killing harmful microorganisms.

questions.question: The solubilities of different solutes in a given solvent can be compared by

options.text: plotting their solubility curves on separate axes
plotting their solubility curves on the same axes
plotting some of the solubility curves on the x-axis and others on the y-axis
plotting their solubility curves on the x-axis only

questions.explanation: Plotting on the same axes allows direct comparison at the same temperatures.

questions.question: Potassium trioxochlorate (V) has a solubility of 1.5 \(\text{mol dm}^{-3}\) at 45\(^\circ\)C. On cooling this solution to 20\(^\circ\)C, the solubility was found to be 0.5 \(\text{mol dm}^{-3}\). What mass of \(\text{KClO}_3\) was crystallized out? [K = 39, Cl = 35.5, O = 16]
questions.explanation: Decrease in solubility \(= 1.5 - 0.5 = 1.0\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}\), so \(1.0\) mol crystallizes per \(1\,\text{dm}^3\). Molar mass of \(\text{KClO}_3\): \(39 + 35.5 + 3(16) = 122.5\,\text{g mol}^{-1}\). Mass crystallized \(= 1.0\times 122.5 = 122.50\,\text{g}\).

questions.question: Which of the following pollutants is associated with brain damage?
questions.explanation: Carbon(II) oxide (CO) reduces oxygen delivery by forming carboxyhaemoglobin; severe oxygen deprivation (hypoxia) can cause brain damage.

questions.question: Which of the following will produce a solution with pH less than 7 at equivalent point?
questions.explanation: A pH below 7 at equivalence is characteristic of a strong acid with a weak base. \(\text{Mg(OH)}_2\) is not a strong alkali (sparingly soluble), so titration with HCl can yield an acidic equivalence solution compared with strong acid–strong base pairs.

questions.question: The number of hydronium ions produced by one molecule of an acid in aqueous solution is its
questions.explanation: Basicity is the number of ionizable hydrogen atoms an acid can donate, i.e., the number of \(\text{H}_3\text{O}^+\) it can produce per molecule.

questions.question: During a titration experiment, 0.05 moles of carbon (IV) oxide is liberated. What is the volume of gas liberated?
questions.explanation: At STP, molar volume \(= 22.4\,\text{dm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1}\). Volume \(= 0.05\times 22.4 = 1.12\,\text{dm}^3\).

questions.question: A major factor considered in selecting a suitable method for preparing a simple salt is its
questions.explanation: Solubility determines whether a salt is prepared by precipitation (insoluble) or by titration/evaporation (soluble).

questions.question: The oxidation number of boron in \(\text{NaBH}_4\) is
questions.explanation: Treat \(\text{NaBH}_4\) as \(\text{Na}^+\) and \(\text{BH}_4^-\). In \(\text{BH}_4^-\), hydrogen is hydride \((-1)\). Let boron be \(x\): \(x + 4(-1) = -1\Rightarrow x-4=-1\Rightarrow x=+3\).

questions.question: \(2\text{Na}_2\text{O}_{2(s)} + 2\text{H}_2\text{O}_{(l)} \rightarrow 4\text{NaOH}_{(s)} + \text{O}_{2(g)}\). The substance that is oxidized in the reaction above is
questions.explanation: Oxygen in peroxide \(\text{Na}_2\text{O}_2\) has oxidation state \(-1\). In \(\text{O}_2\) it is 0. Increase from \(-1\) to 0 is oxidation, so \(\text{Na}_2\text{O}_2\) (specifically its oxygen) is oxidized.

questions.question: What number of moles of \(\text{Cu}^{2+}\) will be deposited by 360 coulombs of electricity? [\(F = 96500\,\text{C mol}^{-1}\)]
questions.explanation: Moles of electrons passed: \(n(e^-) = \frac{Q}{F} = \frac{360}{96500} = 3.73\times 10^{-3}\,\text{mol}\) (approx). For \(\text{Cu}^{2+} + 2e^- \rightarrow \text{Cu}\), moles of Cu deposited \(= \frac{n(e^-)}{2} = \frac{3.73\times 10^{-3}}{2} = 1.865\times 10^{-3}\approx 1.87\times 10^{-3}\,\text{mol}\).

questions.question: A metal M displaces zinc from \(\text{ZnCl}_2\) solution. This shows that

options.text: electrons flow from zinc to M
M is more electropositive than zinc
M is more electronegative than zinc
zinc is more electropositive than M

questions.explanation: Displacement means M is more reactive (more easily oxidized) than Zn, i.e., more electropositive.

questions.question: \(\text{CO}_{(g)} + \text{H}_2\text{O}_{(g)} \rightarrow \text{CO}_{2(g)} + \text{H}_{2(g)}\). Calculate the standard heat change of the reaction above, if the standard enthalpies of formation (kJ mol\(^{-1}\)) of \(\text{CO}_{2(g)}\), \(\text{H}_2\text{O}_{(g)}\) and \(\text{CO}_{(g)}\) are \(-394\), \(-242\) and \(-110\) respectively.
questions.explanation: Use \(\Delta H^\circ = \sum \Delta H_f^\circ(\text{products}) - \sum \Delta H_f^\circ(\text{reactants})\). Products: \(-394 + 0\). Reactants: \(-110 + (-242) = -352\). Thus \(\Delta H^\circ = -394 - (-352) = -42\,\text{kJ mol}^{-1}\).

questions.question: An increase in entropy can best be illustrated by
questions.explanation: Mixing gases increases randomness/disorder (higher entropy). Freezing, condensation, and solidification reduce entropy.

questions.question: The highest rate of production of carbon (IV) oxide can be achieved using
questions.explanation: Reaction rate increases with higher acid concentration and larger surface area; powdered \(\text{CaCO}_3\) has greater surface area and 0.10 \(\text{mol dm}^{-3}\) is the highest concentration.

questions.question: \(2\text{HCl}_{(aq)} + \text{CaCO}_{3(s)} \rightarrow \text{CaCl}_{2(s)} + \text{CO}_{2(g)} + \text{H}_2\text{O}_{(l)}\). From the reaction above, which of the curves represents the production of \(\text{CO}_2\) gas as dilute HCl is added?
questions.explanation: In the provided image, the curves labeled L, M, N and P are not visible (only the apparatus and text are visible). Since the identifying graph/curves are missing from the upload, the correct option cannot be determined from the images alone.

questions.question: \(2\text{CO}_{(g)} + \text{O}_{2(g)} \rightleftharpoons 2\text{CO}_{2(g)}\). In the reaction above, high pressure will favour the forward reaction because

options.text: the reaction is in dynamic equilibrium
the process occurs with a decrease in volume

questions.explanation: Reactants have 3 moles of gas, products have 2 moles. Higher pressure favors the side with fewer moles of gas (smaller volume), i.e., the forward reaction.

questions.question: A piece of filter paper moistened with lead (II) ethanoate solution turns black when the paper is dropped into a gas likely to be
questions.explanation: Hydrogen sulphide reacts with lead(II) ions to form black lead(II) sulphide, \(\text{PbS}\).

questions.question: Which of the following gases has a characteristic pungent smell, turns red litmus paper blue and forms dense white fumes with hydrogen chloride gas?
questions.explanation: Ammonia is basic (turns red litmus blue) and reacts with HCl to form \(\text{NH}_4\text{Cl}\), seen as dense white fumes.

questions.question: Commercial bleaching can be carried out using
questions.explanation: Both chlorine (oxidizing bleach) and sulphur(IV) oxide (reducing bleach) are used in bleaching processes; the option listing two bleaching agents is C.

questions.question: Mineral acids are usually added to commercial hydrogen peroxide to

options.text: reduce it to water and oxygen

questions.explanation: Acidic conditions help stabilize hydrogen peroxide, reducing its rate of decomposition.

questions.question: Which of the following compounds will burn with a brick-red colour in a nonluminous Bunsen flame?
questions.explanation: A brick-red flame indicates \(\text{Ca}^{2+}\). The calcium-containing compound is option C.

questions.question: The purest form of iron which contains only about 0.1% carbon is
questions.explanation: Wrought iron has very low carbon content (about 0.1% or less) compared with pig iron and cast iron.

questions.question: A common characteristic between zinc and the other transition elements is the ability to
questions.explanation: Zinc forms complex ions (e.g., \([\text{Zn(OH)}_4]^{2-}\), \([\text{Zn(NH}_3)_4]^{2+}\)). It does not commonly show variable oxidation states and its ions are generally colourless.

questions.question: Which of the following metals is the least reactive?
questions.explanation: Gold (Au) is a noble metal and is the least reactive among the listed metals.

questions.question: Geometric isomerism can exist in
questions.explanation: Hex-3-ene has a \(\text{C=C}\) where each carbon has two different substituents, allowing cis/trans isomers. Terminal alkenes like prop-1-ene and 3-methylbut-1-ene do not show geometric isomerism.

questions.question: Alkanals can be distinguished from alkanones by the reaction with
questions.explanation: Aldehydes reduce Fehling’s solution to brick-red \(\text{Cu}_2\text{O}\); ketones do not under the same conditions.

questions.question: The isomers of \(\text{C}_3\text{H}_8\text{O}\) are
questions.explanation: \(\text{C}_3\text{H}_8\text{O}\) corresponds to propanol alcohols: propan-1-ol and propan-2-ol.

questions.question: Carbohydrates are large molecules with the molecular formula \(\text{C}_x(\text{H}_2\text{O})_y\). In which of the following pairs is x not equal to y?
questions.explanation: Monosaccharides like glucose/fructose typically have \(x=y\) (e.g., \(\text{C}_6\text{H}_{12}\text{O}_6\)). Disaccharides like maltose have \(x\neq y\) (e.g., \(\text{C}_{12}\text{H}_{22}\text{O}_{11}\)), so any pair including maltose fits; option B does.

questions.question: A compound contains 40.0% C, 6.7% H, 53.3% O. If the molecular mass of the compound is 180, its molecular formula is [C = 12, H = 1, O = 16]
questions.explanation: In 100 g: \(n_C=\frac{40.0}{12}=3.333\), \(n_H=\frac{6.7}{1}=6.7\), \(n_O=\frac{53.3}{16}=3.331\). Divide by 3.331: C:H:O \(\approx 1:2:1\) → empirical formula \(\text{CH}_2\text{O}\) (mass 30). Factor \(=\frac{180}{30}=6\). Molecular formula \(=(\text{CH}_2\text{O})_6=\text{C}_6\text{H}_{12}\text{O}_6\).

questions.question: The alkyne that will give a white precipitate with silver trioxonitrate (V) is
questions.explanation: White precipitate with silver nitrate (in ammoniacal conditions) indicates a terminal alkyne \((\equiv\text{C–H})\). Only option C is terminal: \(\ldots\text{C}\equiv\text{CH}\).

questions.question: The saponification of an alkanoate to produce soap and alkanol involves
questions.explanation: Saponification is alkaline hydrolysis of an ester to give an alcohol and a carboxylate salt (soap).

questions.question: 2-methyl propan-2-ol is an example of a
questions.explanation: The carbon bearing the \(-\text{OH}\) group is bonded to three other carbons, so it is a tertiary alcohol.

questions.question: The final oxidation product of alkanol, alkanal and alkanoes is
questions.explanation: Primary alkanols oxidize to alkanals and further to alkanoic acids; alkanals also oxidize to alkanoic acids.

questions.question: Ethanol reacts with concentrated tetraoxosulphate (VI) acid at a temperature above 170\(^\circ\)C to form
questions.explanation: At about 170\(^\circ\)C, concentrated \(\text{H}_2\text{SO}_4\) dehydrates ethanol to ethene: \(\text{C}_2\text{H}_5\text{OH} \rightarrow \text{C}_2\text{H}_4 + \text{H}_2\text{O}\).

questions.question: An example of oxidation - reduction enzyme is
questions.explanation: Dehydrogenases catalyze redox reactions by transferring hydrogen/electrons between molecules.
